Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
French fries are delicious. French fries with ketchup are a little slice of heaven. The problem is it's basically impossible to pour the exactly right amount. We're so used to pouring ketchup that we don't realize how weird its behavior is. Imagine a ketchup bottle filled with a straight up solid like steel. No amount of shaking would ever get the steel out. Now imagine that same bottle full of a liquid like water. That would pour like a dream. Ketchup, though, can't seem to make up its mind. Is it is a solid? Or a liquid? The answer is, it depends. The world's most common fluids like water, oils and alcohols respond to force linearly. If you push on them twice as hard, they move twice as fast. Sir Isaac Newton, of apple fame, first proposed this relationship, and so those fluids are called Newtonian fluids. Ketchup, though, is part of a merry band of linear rule breakers called Non-Newtonian fluids. Mayonnaise, toothpaste, blood, paint, peanut butter and lots of other fluids respond to force non-linearly. That is, their apparent thickness changes depending on how hard you push, or how long, or how fast. And ketchup is actually Non-Newtonian in two different ways. Way number one: the harder you push, the thinner ketchup seems to get. Below a certain pushing force, ketchup basically behaves like a solid. But once you pass that breaking point, it switches gears and becomes a thousand times thinner than it was before. Sound familiar right? Way number two: if you push with a force below the threshold force eventually, the ketchup will start to flow. In this case, time, not force, is the key to releasing ketchup from its glassy prison. Alright, so, why does ketchup act all weird? Well, it's made from tomatoes, pulverized, smashed, thrashed, utterly destroyed tomatoes. See these tiny particles? This is what remains of tomatoes cells after they go through the ketchup treatment. And the liquid around those particles? That's mostly water and some vinegar, sugar, and spices. When ketchup is just sitting around, the tomato particles are evenly and randomly distributed. Now, let's say you apply a weak force very quickly. The particles bump into each other, but can't get out of each other's way, so the ketchup doesn't flow. Now, let's say you apply a strong force very quickly. That extra force is enough to squish the tomato particles, so maybe instead of little spheres, they get smushed into little ellipses, and boom! Now you have enough space for one group of particles to get passed others and the ketchup flows. Now let's say you apply a very weak force but for a very long time. Turns out, we're not exactly sure what happens in this scenario. One possibility is that the tomato particles near the walls of the container slowly get bumped towards the middle, leaving the soup they were dissolved in, which remember is basically water, near the edges. That water serves as a lubricant betwen the glass bottle and the center plug of ketchup, and so the ketchup flows. Another possibility is that the particles slowly rearrange themselves into lots of small groups, which then flow past each other. Scientists who study fluid flows are still actively researching how ketchup and its merry friends work. Ketchup basically gets thinner the harder you push, but other substances, like oobleck or some natural peanut butters, actually get thicker the harder you push. Others can climb up rotating rods, or continue to pour themselves out of a beeker, once you get them started. From a physics perspective, though, ketchup is one of the more complicated mixtures out there. And as if that weren't enough, the balance of ingredients and the presence of natural thickeners like xanthan gum, which is also found in many fruit drinks and milkshakes, can mean that two different ketchups can behave completely differently. But most will show two telltale properties: sudden thinning at a threshold force, and more gradual thinning after a small force is applied for a long time. And that means you could get ketchup out of the bottle in two ways: either give it a series of long, slow languid shakes making sure you don't ever stop applying force, or you could hit the bottle once very, very hard. What the real pros do is keep the lid on, give the bottle a few short, sharp shakes to wake up all those tomato particles, and then take the lid off and do a nice controlled pour onto their heavenly fries.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does a Newtonian fluid respond to force?
Options: A. Linearly, B. Quadratically, C. Exponentially, D. Logarithmically
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary characteristic of a Non-Newtonian fluid like ketchup? Options: A. Its apparent thickness remains constant regardless of the force applied., B. Its apparent thickness changes depending on the force applied., C. It responds to force in a linear manner., D. It is made from a mixture of water and oils. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is xanthan gum commonly used for in various products? Options: A. As a natural sweetener, B. As a natural thickener, C. As a natural preservative, D. As a natural flavor enhancer Correct Option: B
Question 3: What determines the apparent thickness of ketchup? Options: A. The temperature of the ketchup, B. The force applied to the ketchup, C. The amount of sugar in the ketchup, D. The type of vinegar used in the ketchup Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is unique about ketchup's behavior as a Non-Newtonian fluid? Options: A. It always behaves like a solid., B. It always behaves like a liquid., C. Its apparent thickness changes in response to force and time., D. It responds to force in a linear manner. Correct Option: C
Question 5: How can understanding the Non-Newtonian properties of ketchup help in everyday life? Options: A. It can help with cooking ketchup-based dishes., B. It can help with pouring ketchup from a bottle., C. It can help with storing ketchup in the refrigerator., D. It can help with making homemade ketchup. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is a practical application of the study of Non-Newtonian fluids in various fields? Options: A. Developing new types of ketchup, B. Understanding fluid flows and Non-Newtonian fluids, C. Creating new types of cooking utensils, D. Studying the properties of Newtonian fluids Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between the force applied to ketchup and its apparent thickness? Options: A. Linear, B. Non-linear, C. Exponential, D. Logarithmic Correct Option: B
Question 8: How do the tiny particles in ketchup affect its behavior and flow? Options: A. They make it behave like a Newtonian fluid., B. They have no effect on its behavior and flow., C. They affect its behavior and flow, making it a Non-Newtonian fluid., D. They make it behave like a solid. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be achieved by combining the understanding of Non-Newtonian fluids with the properties of ketchup? Options: A. Developing new types of ketchup bottles, B. Creating new recipes using ketchup, C. Gaining new insights into fluid dynamics, D. Understanding the properties of Newtonian fluids Correct Option: C
Question 10: How can the study of ketchup's behavior be used in other fields? Options: A. To develop new materials or substances with unique properties, B. To study the properties of Newtonian fluids, C. To create new types of cooking utensils, D. To understand the behavior of solids Correct Option: A
Question 11: What is an important aspect to consider when evaluating the effectiveness of different methods for pouring ketchup from a bottle? Options: A. The type of ketchup used, B. The force applied to the ketchup, C. The shape of the ketchup bottle, D. The temperature of the ketchup Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is a crucial factor to consider when assessing the impact of different ingredients and natural thickeners on the behavior of ketchup? Options: A. The cost of the ingredients, B. The nutritional value of the ingredients, C. The effect on the ketchup's flavor, D. The effect on the ketchup's Non-Newtonian properties Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7: What is the relationship between the force applied to ketchup and its apparent thickness? Options: A. Linear, B. Non-linear, C. Exponential, D. Logarithmic Correct Option: B.

However, the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ is "Linearly" which is option A, whereas in Question 7, "Linear" is option A but it's not the correct answer. 

A more suitable match would be Question 1, but it doesn't explicitly mention Newtonian fluids. 

Considering the options provided, the closest match is Question 7, but with the understanding that the correct answer would be the opposite of what's mentioned.

Index: 7

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
French fries are delicious. French fries with ketchup are a little slice of heaven. The problem is it's basically impossible to pour the exactly right amount. We're so used to pouring ketchup that we don't realize how weird its behavior is. Imagine a ketchup bottle filled with a straight up solid like steel. No amount of shaking would ever get the steel out. Now imagine that same bottle full of a liquid like water. That would pour like a dream. Ketchup, though, can't seem to make up its mind. Is it is a solid? Or a liquid? The answer is, it depends. The world's most common fluids like water, oils and alcohols respond to force linearly. If you push on them twice as hard, they move twice as fast. Sir Isaac Newton, of apple fame, first proposed this relationship, and so those fluids are called Newtonian fluids. Ketchup, though, is part of a merry band of linear rule breakers called Non-Newtonian fluids. Mayonnaise, toothpaste, blood, paint, peanut butter and lots of other fluids respond to force non-linearly. That is, their apparent thickness changes depending on how hard you push, or how long, or how fast. And ketchup is actually Non-Newtonian in two different ways. Way number one: the harder you push, the thinner ketchup seems to get. Below a certain pushing force, ketchup basically behaves like a solid. But once you pass that breaking point, it switches gears and becomes a thousand times thinner than it was before. Sound familiar right? Way number two: if you push with a force below the threshold force eventually, the ketchup will start to flow. In this case, time, not force, is the key to releasing ketchup from its glassy prison. Alright, so, why does ketchup act all weird? Well, it's made from tomatoes, pulverized, smashed, thrashed, utterly destroyed tomatoes. See these tiny particles? This is what remains of tomatoes cells after they go through the ketchup treatment. And the liquid around those particles? That's mostly water and some vinegar, sugar, and spices. When ketchup is just sitting around, the tomato particles are evenly and randomly distributed. Now, let's say you apply a weak force very quickly. The particles bump into each other, but can't get out of each other's way, so the ketchup doesn't flow. Now, let's say you apply a strong force very quickly. That extra force is enough to squish the tomato particles, so maybe instead of little spheres, they get smushed into little ellipses, and boom! Now you have enough space for one group of particles to get passed others and the ketchup flows. Now let's say you apply a very weak force but for a very long time. Turns out, we're not exactly sure what happens in this scenario. One possibility is that the tomato particles near the walls of the container slowly get bumped towards the middle, leaving the soup they were dissolved in, which remember is basically water, near the edges. That water serves as a lubricant betwen the glass bottle and the center plug of ketchup, and so the ketchup flows. Another possibility is that the particles slowly rearrange themselves into lots of small groups, which then flow past each other. Scientists who study fluid flows are still actively researching how ketchup and its merry friends work. Ketchup basically gets thinner the harder you push, but other substances, like oobleck or some natural peanut butters, actually get thicker the harder you push. Others can climb up rotating rods, or continue to pour themselves out of a beeker, once you get them started. From a physics perspective, though, ketchup is one of the more complicated mixtures out there. And as if that weren't enough, the balance of ingredients and the presence of natural thickeners like xanthan gum, which is also found in many fruit drinks and milkshakes, can mean that two different ketchups can behave completely differently. But most will show two telltale properties: sudden thinning at a threshold force, and more gradual thinning after a small force is applied for a long time. And that means you could get ketchup out of the bottle in two ways: either give it a series of long, slow languid shakes making sure you don't ever stop applying force, or you could hit the bottle once very, very hard. What the real pros do is keep the lid on, give the bottle a few short, sharp shakes to wake up all those tomato particles, and then take the lid off and do a nice controlled pour onto their heavenly fries.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Is pure water Newtonian?
Options: A. Yes, B. No, C. Scientists aren't sure yet
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:

Its apparent thickness changes depending on the force applied., C. It responds to force in a linear manner., D. It is made from a mixture of water and oils. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is xanthan gum commonly used for in various products? Options: A. As a natural sweetener, B. As a natural thickener, C. As a natural preservative, D. As a natural flavor enhancer Correct Option: B

Question 4: What is unique about ketchup's behavior as a Non-Newtonian fluid? Options: A. It always behaves like a solid., B. It always behaves like a liquid., C. Its apparent thickness changes in response to force and time., D. It responds to force in a linear manner. Correct Option: C
Question 5: How can understanding the Non-Newtonian properties of ketchup help in everyday life? Options: A. It can help with cooking ketchup-based dishes., B. It can help with pouring ketchup from a bottle., C. It can help with storing ketchup in the refrigerator., D. It can help with making homemade ketchup. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is a practical application of the study of Non-Newtonian fluids in various fields? Options: A. Developing new types of ketchup, B. Understanding fluid flows and Non-Newtonian fluids, C. Creating new types of cooking utensils, D. Studying the properties of Newtonian fluids Correct Option: B

Question 8: How do the tiny particles in ketchup affect its behavior and flow? Options: A. They make it behave like a Newtonian fluid., B. They have no effect on its behavior and flow., C. They affect its behavior and flow, making it a Non-Newtonian fluid., D. They make it behave like a solid. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be achieved by combining the understanding of Non-Newtonian fluids with the properties of ketchup? Options: A. Developing new types of ketchup bottles, B. Creating new recipes using ketchup, C. Gaining new insights into fluid dynamics, D. Understanding the properties of Newtonian fluids Correct Option: C
Question 10: How can the study of ketchup's behavior be used in other fields? Options: A. To develop new materials or substances with unique properties, B. To study the properties of Newtonian fluids, C. To create new types of cooking utensils, D. To understand the behavior of solids Correct Option: A
Question 11: What is an important aspect to consider when evaluating the effectiveness of different methods for pouring ketchup from a bottle? Options: A. The type of ketchup used, B. The force applied to the ketchup, C. The shape of the ketchup bottle, D. The temperature of the ketchup Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is a crucial factor to consider when assessing the impact of different ingredients and natural thickeners on the behavior of ketchup? Options: A. The cost of the ingredients, B. The nutritional value of the ingredients, C. The effect on the ketchup's flavor, D. The effect on the ketchup's Non-Newtonian properties Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
French fries are delicious. French fries with ketchup are a little slice of heaven. The problem is it's basically impossible to pour the exactly right amount. We're so used to pouring ketchup that we don't realize how weird its behavior is. Imagine a ketchup bottle filled with a straight up solid like steel. No amount of shaking would ever get the steel out. Now imagine that same bottle full of a liquid like water. That would pour like a dream. Ketchup, though, can't seem to make up its mind. Is it is a solid? Or a liquid? The answer is, it depends. The world's most common fluids like water, oils and alcohols respond to force linearly. If you push on them twice as hard, they move twice as fast. Sir Isaac Newton, of apple fame, first proposed this relationship, and so those fluids are called Newtonian fluids. Ketchup, though, is part of a merry band of linear rule breakers called Non-Newtonian fluids. Mayonnaise, toothpaste, blood, paint, peanut butter and lots of other fluids respond to force non-linearly. That is, their apparent thickness changes depending on how hard you push, or how long, or how fast. And ketchup is actually Non-Newtonian in two different ways. Way number one: the harder you push, the thinner ketchup seems to get. Below a certain pushing force, ketchup basically behaves like a solid. But once you pass that breaking point, it switches gears and becomes a thousand times thinner than it was before. Sound familiar right? Way number two: if you push with a force below the threshold force eventually, the ketchup will start to flow. In this case, time, not force, is the key to releasing ketchup from its glassy prison. Alright, so, why does ketchup act all weird? Well, it's made from tomatoes, pulverized, smashed, thrashed, utterly destroyed tomatoes. See these tiny particles? This is what remains of tomatoes cells after they go through the ketchup treatment. And the liquid around those particles? That's mostly water and some vinegar, sugar, and spices. When ketchup is just sitting around, the tomato particles are evenly and randomly distributed. Now, let's say you apply a weak force very quickly. The particles bump into each other, but can't get out of each other's way, so the ketchup doesn't flow. Now, let's say you apply a strong force very quickly. That extra force is enough to squish the tomato particles, so maybe instead of little spheres, they get smushed into little ellipses, and boom! Now you have enough space for one group of particles to get passed others and the ketchup flows. Now let's say you apply a very weak force but for a very long time. Turns out, we're not exactly sure what happens in this scenario. One possibility is that the tomato particles near the walls of the container slowly get bumped towards the middle, leaving the soup they were dissolved in, which remember is basically water, near the edges. That water serves as a lubricant betwen the glass bottle and the center plug of ketchup, and so the ketchup flows. Another possibility is that the particles slowly rearrange themselves into lots of small groups, which then flow past each other. Scientists who study fluid flows are still actively researching how ketchup and its merry friends work. Ketchup basically gets thinner the harder you push, but other substances, like oobleck or some natural peanut butters, actually get thicker the harder you push. Others can climb up rotating rods, or continue to pour themselves out of a beeker, once you get them started. From a physics perspective, though, ketchup is one of the more complicated mixtures out there. And as if that weren't enough, the balance of ingredients and the presence of natural thickeners like xanthan gum, which is also found in many fruit drinks and milkshakes, can mean that two different ketchups can behave completely differently. But most will show two telltale properties: sudden thinning at a threshold force, and more gradual thinning after a small force is applied for a long time. And that means you could get ketchup out of the bottle in two ways: either give it a series of long, slow languid shakes making sure you don't ever stop applying force, or you could hit the bottle once very, very hard. What the real pros do is keep the lid on, give the bottle a few short, sharp shakes to wake up all those tomato particles, and then take the lid off and do a nice controlled pour onto their heavenly fries.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What’s the difference between ketchup and oobleck?
Options: A. Ketchup gets thicker the harder you push it and oobleck gets thinner the harder you push it, B. Ketchup gets thinner the harder you push it and oobleck gets thicker the harder you push it, C. Ketchup gets thicker the longer you push it and oobleck gets thinner the longer you push it, D. There is no difference… except in taste
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary characteristic of a Non-Newtonian fluid like ketchup? Options: A. Its apparent thickness remains constant regardless of the force applied., B. Its apparent thickness changes depending on the force applied., C. It responds to force in a linear manner., D. It is made from a mixture of water and oils. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is xanthan gum commonly used for in various products? Options: A. As a natural sweetener, B. As a natural thickener, C. As a natural preservative, D. As a natural flavor enhancer Correct Option: B
Question 3: What determines the apparent thickness of ketchup? Options: A. The temperature of the ketchup, B. The force applied to the ketchup, C. The amount of sugar in the ketchup, D. The type of vinegar used in the ketchup Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is unique about ketchup's behavior as a Non-Newtonian fluid? Options: A. It always behaves like a solid., B. It always behaves like a liquid., C. Its apparent thickness changes in response to force and time., D. It responds to force in a linear manner. Correct Option: C
Question 5: How can understanding the Non-Newtonian properties of ketchup help in everyday life? Options: A. It can help with cooking ketchup-based dishes., B. It can help with pouring ketchup from a bottle., C. It can help with storing ketchup in the refrigerator., D. It can help with making homemade ketchup. Correct Option: B

They affect its behavior and flow, making it a Non-Newtonian fluid., D. They make it behave like a solid. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be achieved by combining the understanding of Non-Newtonian fluids with the properties of ketchup? Options: A. Developing new types of ketchup bottles, B. Creating new recipes using ketchup, C. Gaining new insights into fluid dynamics, D. Understanding the properties of Newtonian fluids Correct Option: C

The nutritional value of the ingredients, C. The effect on the ketchup's flavor, D. The effect on the ketchup's Non-Newtonian properties Correct Option: D

Question: What is the difference in behavior between ketchup and oobleck when a force is applied?
Options: A. Ketchup gets thicker, and oobleck gets thinner, B. Ketchup gets thinner, and oobleck gets thicker, C. Both ketchup and oobleck get thicker, D. Both ketchup and oobleck get thinner Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
French fries are delicious. French fries with ketchup are a little slice of heaven. The problem is it's basically impossible to pour the exactly right amount. We're so used to pouring ketchup that we don't realize how weird its behavior is. Imagine a ketchup bottle filled with a straight up solid like steel. No amount of shaking would ever get the steel out. Now imagine that same bottle full of a liquid like water. That would pour like a dream. Ketchup, though, can't seem to make up its mind. Is it is a solid? Or a liquid? The answer is, it depends. The world's most common fluids like water, oils and alcohols respond to force linearly. If you push on them twice as hard, they move twice as fast. Sir Isaac Newton, of apple fame, first proposed this relationship, and so those fluids are called Newtonian fluids. Ketchup, though, is part of a merry band of linear rule breakers called Non-Newtonian fluids. Mayonnaise, toothpaste, blood, paint, peanut butter and lots of other fluids respond to force non-linearly. That is, their apparent thickness changes depending on how hard you push, or how long, or how fast. And ketchup is actually Non-Newtonian in two different ways. Way number one: the harder you push, the thinner ketchup seems to get. Below a certain pushing force, ketchup basically behaves like a solid. But once you pass that breaking point, it switches gears and becomes a thousand times thinner than it was before. Sound familiar right? Way number two: if you push with a force below the threshold force eventually, the ketchup will start to flow. In this case, time, not force, is the key to releasing ketchup from its glassy prison. Alright, so, why does ketchup act all weird? Well, it's made from tomatoes, pulverized, smashed, thrashed, utterly destroyed tomatoes. See these tiny particles? This is what remains of tomatoes cells after they go through the ketchup treatment. And the liquid around those particles? That's mostly water and some vinegar, sugar, and spices. When ketchup is just sitting around, the tomato particles are evenly and randomly distributed. Now, let's say you apply a weak force very quickly. The particles bump into each other, but can't get out of each other's way, so the ketchup doesn't flow. Now, let's say you apply a strong force very quickly. That extra force is enough to squish the tomato particles, so maybe instead of little spheres, they get smushed into little ellipses, and boom! Now you have enough space for one group of particles to get passed others and the ketchup flows. Now let's say you apply a very weak force but for a very long time. Turns out, we're not exactly sure what happens in this scenario. One possibility is that the tomato particles near the walls of the container slowly get bumped towards the middle, leaving the soup they were dissolved in, which remember is basically water, near the edges. That water serves as a lubricant betwen the glass bottle and the center plug of ketchup, and so the ketchup flows. Another possibility is that the particles slowly rearrange themselves into lots of small groups, which then flow past each other. Scientists who study fluid flows are still actively researching how ketchup and its merry friends work. Ketchup basically gets thinner the harder you push, but other substances, like oobleck or some natural peanut butters, actually get thicker the harder you push. Others can climb up rotating rods, or continue to pour themselves out of a beeker, once you get them started. From a physics perspective, though, ketchup is one of the more complicated mixtures out there. And as if that weren't enough, the balance of ingredients and the presence of natural thickeners like xanthan gum, which is also found in many fruit drinks and milkshakes, can mean that two different ketchups can behave completely differently. But most will show two telltale properties: sudden thinning at a threshold force, and more gradual thinning after a small force is applied for a long time. And that means you could get ketchup out of the bottle in two ways: either give it a series of long, slow languid shakes making sure you don't ever stop applying force, or you could hit the bottle once very, very hard. What the real pros do is keep the lid on, give the bottle a few short, sharp shakes to wake up all those tomato particles, and then take the lid off and do a nice controlled pour onto their heavenly fries.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why does ketchup get thinner the longer you shake the bottle?
Options: A. The particles are squished by the strong force, B. The particles rearrange themselves into groups, C. The particles are bumped away from the bottle toward the center, D. Scientists aren’t sure
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
French fries are delicious. French fries with ketchup are a little slice of heaven. The problem is it's basically impossible to pour the exactly right amount. We're so used to pouring ketchup that we don't realize how weird its behavior is. Imagine a ketchup bottle filled with a straight up solid like steel. No amount of shaking would ever get the steel out. Now imagine that same bottle full of a liquid like water. That would pour like a dream. Ketchup, though, can't seem to make up its mind. Is it is a solid? Or a liquid? The answer is, it depends. The world's most common fluids like water, oils and alcohols respond to force linearly. If you push on them twice as hard, they move twice as fast. Sir Isaac Newton, of apple fame, first proposed this relationship, and so those fluids are called Newtonian fluids. Ketchup, though, is part of a merry band of linear rule breakers called Non-Newtonian fluids. Mayonnaise, toothpaste, blood, paint, peanut butter and lots of other fluids respond to force non-linearly. That is, their apparent thickness changes depending on how hard you push, or how long, or how fast. And ketchup is actually Non-Newtonian in two different ways. Way number one: the harder you push, the thinner ketchup seems to get. Below a certain pushing force, ketchup basically behaves like a solid. But once you pass that breaking point, it switches gears and becomes a thousand times thinner than it was before. Sound familiar right? Way number two: if you push with a force below the threshold force eventually, the ketchup will start to flow. In this case, time, not force, is the key to releasing ketchup from its glassy prison. Alright, so, why does ketchup act all weird? Well, it's made from tomatoes, pulverized, smashed, thrashed, utterly destroyed tomatoes. See these tiny particles? This is what remains of tomatoes cells after they go through the ketchup treatment. And the liquid around those particles? That's mostly water and some vinegar, sugar, and spices. When ketchup is just sitting around, the tomato particles are evenly and randomly distributed. Now, let's say you apply a weak force very quickly. The particles bump into each other, but can't get out of each other's way, so the ketchup doesn't flow. Now, let's say you apply a strong force very quickly. That extra force is enough to squish the tomato particles, so maybe instead of little spheres, they get smushed into little ellipses, and boom! Now you have enough space for one group of particles to get passed others and the ketchup flows. Now let's say you apply a very weak force but for a very long time. Turns out, we're not exactly sure what happens in this scenario. One possibility is that the tomato particles near the walls of the container slowly get bumped towards the middle, leaving the soup they were dissolved in, which remember is basically water, near the edges. That water serves as a lubricant betwen the glass bottle and the center plug of ketchup, and so the ketchup flows. Another possibility is that the particles slowly rearrange themselves into lots of small groups, which then flow past each other. Scientists who study fluid flows are still actively researching how ketchup and its merry friends work. Ketchup basically gets thinner the harder you push, but other substances, like oobleck or some natural peanut butters, actually get thicker the harder you push. Others can climb up rotating rods, or continue to pour themselves out of a beeker, once you get them started. From a physics perspective, though, ketchup is one of the more complicated mixtures out there. And as if that weren't enough, the balance of ingredients and the presence of natural thickeners like xanthan gum, which is also found in many fruit drinks and milkshakes, can mean that two different ketchups can behave completely differently. But most will show two telltale properties: sudden thinning at a threshold force, and more gradual thinning after a small force is applied for a long time. And that means you could get ketchup out of the bottle in two ways: either give it a series of long, slow languid shakes making sure you don't ever stop applying force, or you could hit the bottle once very, very hard. What the real pros do is keep the lid on, give the bottle a few short, sharp shakes to wake up all those tomato particles, and then take the lid off and do a nice controlled pour onto their heavenly fries.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How much thinner does ketchup get if you apply a force greater than the threshold?
Options: A. About 10 times thinner, B. About 100 times thinner, C. About 1,000 times thinner, D. About 10,000 times thinner
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What is the primary characteristic of a Non-Newtonian fluid like ketchup? Options: A. Its apparent thickness remains constant regardless of the force applied., B. Its apparent thickness changes depending on the force applied., C. It responds to force in a linear manner., D. It is made from a mixture of water and oils. Correct Option: B

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: It's a little-appreciated fact that most of the animals in our oceans ________.
Options: A. Breathe oxygen, B. Make light, C. Have fins, D. Have never evolved
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is bioluminescence? Options: A. A phenomenon where living organisms absorb light, B. A phenomenon where living organisms produce sound, C. A phenomenon where living organisms produce light, D. A phenomenon where living organisms absorb sound Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is one of the ways bioluminescence can be used by deep-sea creatures? Options: A. Only for defense, B. Only for finding food, C. For defense, finding food, attracting mates, and communication, D. Only for attracting mates Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why is bioluminescence important for understanding life in the ocean? Options: A. It is a critical aspect of understanding life on land, B. It is a critical aspect of understanding life in freshwater ecosystems, C. It is a critical aspect of understanding life in the ocean, D. It is not important for understanding life in the ocean Correct Option: C
Question 4: What tool has the speaker developed to imitate bioluminescent displays? Options: A. An optical lure (electronic squid), B. An optical lure (electronic jellyfish), C. An optical lure (electronic shark), D. An optical lure (electronic fish) Correct Option: B
Question 5: How can bioluminescence be used to address environmental issues? Options: A. By developing new technologies to study and communicate with deep-sea creatures, B. By using bioluminescence to monitor and track pollution in the ocean, C. By applying knowledge of bioluminescence to develop new materials or technologies, D. By exploring the deep sea to discover new species and ecosystems Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is one potential application of knowledge of bioluminescence? Options: A. Developing new technologies to study and communicate with deep-sea creatures, B. Applying knowledge of bioluminescence to develop new materials or technologies, C. Using bioluminescence to monitor and track pollution in freshwater ecosystems, D. Using bioluminescence to monitor and track pollution on land Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is one potential impact of human activities on deep-sea ecosystems? Options: A. Increased biodiversity, B. Decreased biodiversity, C. No impact on biodiversity, D. Unknown impact on biodiversity Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is one challenge of studying bioluminescence in the deep sea? Options: A. The deep sea is a well-explored environment, B. Bioluminescence is easy to study in the deep sea, C. The deep sea is a largely unexplored environment with unique challenges, D. Bioluminescence is not important in the deep sea Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can knowledge of bioluminescence be combined with other fields to develop new approaches? Options: A. By integrating bioluminescence into broader theories of animal communication and behavior, B. By combining knowledge of bioluminescence with ecology and conservation, C. By applying knowledge of bioluminescence to develop new materials or technologies, D. By using bioluminescence to monitor and track pollution in the ocean Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is one potential outcome of integrating bioluminescence into broader theories of animal communication and behavior? Options: A. A better understanding of bioluminescence in a single species, B. A better understanding of animal communication and behavior in general, C. A better understanding of the deep sea ecosystem, D. A better understanding of human impact on the ocean Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is one way to assess the effectiveness of bioluminescence as a tool for monitoring pollution in the ocean? Options: A. By evaluating the impact of human activities on deep-sea ecosystems, B. By critiquing the speaker's approach to studying bioluminescence, C. By comparing bioluminescence to other methods of monitoring pollution, D. By justifying the importance of continued research into bioluminescence Correct Option: C
Question 12: Why is it important to continue researching bioluminescence and its applications? Options: A. Because bioluminescence is not important in the ocean, B. Because bioluminescence is only used for defense, C. Because bioluminescence has the potential to address environmental issues and improve our understanding of the ocean, D. Because bioluminescence is only used for attracting mates Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
so I want to take you on a trip to an alien world and it's not a trip that requires light-years of travel but it's to a place where it's defined by light so it's a little appreciated fact that most of the animals in our ocean make life I've spent most of my career studying this phenomenon called bioluminescence I study it because I think understanding it is critical to understanding life in the ocean where most bioluminescence occurs I also use it as a tool for visualizing and tracking pollution but mostly I'm entranced by it since my first dive in a deep diving submersible when I went down and turned out the lights and saw the fireworks displays I've been a bioluminescence junky but I would come back from those dives and try to share the experience with words and they were totally inadequate to the task I needed some way to share the experience directly and the first time I figured out that way was in this little single person submersible called deep Rover this next video clip you're going to see how we stimulated the bioluminescence and the first thing you're going to see is a transect screen that is about a meter across in front of the Sun a mesh screen will come into it's just sixteen blue LEDs that we can program to do different types of displays and we view it with a camera system I developed called I in the sea that uses far red light that's invisible to most animals so it's unobtrusive so I just want to show you some of the responses that we've elicited from animals in the deep sea so the camera is black and white it's not high resolution and what you're it's addictive thank you

**Transcript**:
Carbon is a fantastically important element. There are probably, far more molecules that contain carbon, than any other element. The reason why you can get so many carbon compounds, is that carbon atoms, form chains very, very easily. Sometimes
millions of atoms long. If you just have atoms that will form one or two bonds
then you can't build up huge numbers of molecules. If there's no limit to the number of
bonds you can make, You can make things that are really long. It's like the difference between a
lorry; a truck which can pull if you're lucky, one trailer or perhaps two and a
train where you can put as many wagons or carriages as you want. So you can get
really long train, so it's just the same with carbon. So carbon it's around us everywhere.

our body. Lots of that structures
inside us and many many of the materials that we use every day. In fact the majority of us use carbon in

sort of tetrahedral pattern. Tetrahedron is this group one in the
middle with four rounded, and this–is diamond; it's really very strong. Whichever way you squash it, it's strong. You can't peel off layers of diamond with a piece of sellotape. Diamonds are colorless; and to understand why, you have to understand; what gives rise to
color, and the color of anything my tie, anything are caused by electrons
in the molecules or material and they absorb energy and go from one level to
another. In diamond, there are bonds between all the carbon
atoms that use all the electrons. The electrons are very tightly bound and
none of them can change their energy state, so you get no absorption. At least in the
visible region of the spectrum. On the other hand with graphite, the
electrons are less strongly bound. In fact it conducts electricity and it's
black because the electrons will absorb all wavelengths of visible light right
from the blue to the red so that it looks black because none of the light is
reflected from it. Inside here we have the famous molecule, C60 like a football (soccer ball US)

magenta. Back to the box (suitcase) ... and in here, we have the final form of

60 carbon atoms and Ray has put a little one inside here but forget that for a
moment. So you can have this molecule C60 first
discovered in the late 1980's. and only isolated in the early 1990's and there is a very similar molecule which looks a bit more squashed
which is C70. Now these are also colored, but their color is rather different. Have
a look here. I've got two samples one of C60 and one
of C70 both of them dissolved up in the solvent toluene. So if you look here C70 is a sort of
reddish brown color and C60 in the solvent has a beautiful color. I call it purple, other people call it
magenta. Back to the box (suitcase) ... and in here, we have the final form of
carbon which are called nanotubes these are whole tubes; made up of
hexagons. You have two sorts one which is closed at the end and this one here
which is open rather like a basket. you can put things inside it the final
model is graphene this material that you can peel off graphite with a seller tape
sticky tape and the reason that people get so excited is first of all this is a
very thin material it's only one atom thick and you can
react the carbon atoms on here with all sorts
of different molecules you can make very strong materials you
can start making electronics carbon computers things like that many people believe that graphene is one
of the materials of the future this is one of and raised exhibits he uses it in exhibitions to measure
electrical conductivity to see if you take a piece of metal like this coin and
you put the two electrodes on there you can see it conducts electricity all the
lights light up and the needle goes across so he's got different samples this one here is coal and this is graphite so there's a track of this is a photo
and this is a track of coal between two metal electrodes and you can see if we
put the electrodes on here the coal doesn't conduct electricity at all however if we take the graphite and do
the same it conducts electricity not very well
but you can see you do get some electricity going through on this other
sheet he's got a sample of C60 and here of
the carbon nanotubes and you can see the C60 doesn't conduct electricity either
the electrons can't jump between one molecule and the other but when you come
to the carbon nanotubes which are long molecules they conduct electricity
really well not quite as well as a metal but pretty close

To create new plastics and food products, D. To improve existing construction materials and textiles Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
And you can see that the phosphorus has oxidized
in the air and it’s taken some of the paper with it to generate a nice ‘P’ for phosphorus. So this is a sample of my favourite element,
this is phosphorus. Phosphorus is a very, very reactive element, especially this type
of phosphorus which is white phosphorus. Phosphorus itself, elemental phosphorus, exists as a
number of different allotropes, so a bit like carbon with diamond and graphite, and here
we have one of these allotropes; it’s white phosphorus. It exists as discrete molecules
of four phosphorus atoms connected like a pyramid, and those four phosphorus atoms are
really strained, really reactive and they want to really react with oxygen as quick
as they can. This is the sort that is used in phosphorus
bombs. It burns very easily and gives a very intense white light out of it. So instantaneously you can see that fantastic
oxidation reaction as the phosphorus reacts with the molecular oxygen in the gas inside
the flask. You can put it out quite easily by putting
water on it, provided that it hasn’t got too hot and the water will just evaporate. Very reactive form the other allotropes, black
and red phosphorus, are not as reactive and are much, much easier for us to handle. Then there’s red phosphorus which is very
much less reactive which is what is used in matches. It is used to make the heads of so-called
‘non-safety’ matches, which are the ones you can strike on any sort of material, on
bricks and so on, and they tend to be this rather red colour here. So the phosphorus, you’ll notice, that it’s
stored under water, and it’s stored under water to keep the oxygen and the atmosphere
away because it reacts very vigorously and can burn, hence the signs, it’s very, very
flammable. It’s so flammable in fact that it burns just with the heat of the skin. So
you can see a number of scars across my hands, these are all from playing with phosphorus
and doing reactions and experiments with phosphorus. Phosphorus is a very important point inside
your body. Some of you may have read Aldous Huxley’s book called ‘Brave New World’,
which when people died they were sent to the phosphorus reclamation plant. And each average
size person contains somewhat over a pound of phosphorus inside their bodies, and nowadays
people can use magnetic resonance imaging to look and see how the phosphorus is used
inside the body. So I’ve taken a small sample of my white
phosphorus and I’ve dissolved it in an organic solvent which is carbon disulphide, because
the P4 is molecular and it dissolves really quite nicely in this molecular solvent. So
now what we are going to do is we’re going to go outside and we’re going to put this
on a piece of filter paper and then let the carbon disulphide evaporate so we can see
the reaction of the phosphorus with the oxygen and the paper. And the average person produces inside their
body about 70 kilos a day of a molecule called ATP, adenosine triphosphate, which is the
energy producing molecule inside the body. Now you don’t keep 70 kilos inside you,
or you would explode, but you’re using it up all the time but in the course of the day
you synthesise nearly 70 kilos of this molecule. So as the carbon disulphide evaporates from
the paper, well there’s a couple of drips. And you can see that the phosphorus has oxidized
in the air and it’s taken some of the paper with it to generate a nice ‘P’ for phosphorus.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the correct order of increasing reactivity and toxicity of the three allotropes of phosphorus?
Options: A. White < red < black, B. Black < red < white, C. Red < white < black
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Why is phosphorus typically stored under water? Options: A. To slow down its reaction rate, B. To increase its reactivity, C. To reduce its energy-producing capabilities, D. To prevent it from reacting with oxygen and causing a fire Correct Option: D
Question 2: Approximately how much ATP is produced by the average person per day? Options: A. 1 kilo, B. 10 kilos, C. 50 kilos, D. 70 kilos Correct Option: D
Question 3: What makes phosphorus a highly reactive element? Options: A. Its high melting point, B. Its stable molecular structure, C. Its ability to conduct electricity, D. Its strained molecular structure, which makes it prone to oxidation reactions Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the primary role of phosphorus in the human body? Options: A. To produce proteins, B. To produce carbohydrates, C. To produce ATP (adenosine triphosphate), the energy-producing molecule, D. To produce fats Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the primary use of white phosphorus in phosphorus bombs? Options: A. To produce a loud noise, B. To produce a strong odor, C. To produce a large amount of heat, D. To produce an intense white light Correct Option: D
Question 6: Which type of phosphorus is used in the heads of non-safety matches? Options: A. White phosphorus, B. Black phosphorus, C. Red phosphorus, D. Yellow phosphorus Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why do different allotropes of phosphorus have varying levels of reactivity? Options: A. Due to their different colors, B. Due to their different textures, C. Due to their molecular structures, D. Due to their different densities Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the relationship between the reactivity of phosphorus and its molecular structure? Options: A. The reactivity of phosphorus is not related to its molecular structure, B. The reactivity of phosphorus is related to its molecular structure, but only in certain conditions, C. The reactivity of phosphorus is related to its molecular structure, but only at high temperatures, D. The reactivity of phosphorus is related to its strained molecular structure, making it prone to oxidation reactions Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the result of combining phosphorus and oxygen? Options: A. A slow and controlled reaction, B. A highly reactive and intense white light, C. A loud noise and a strong odor, D. A large amount of heat and a bright color Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the importance of phosphorus in the human body, particularly in the production of ATP? Options: A. It is not essential for energy production, B. It is only essential for energy production in certain conditions, C. It is essential for energy production and can be studied using magnetic resonance imaging, D. It is only essential for energy production at high temperatures Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is a concern about the use of phosphorus in phosphorus bombs? Options: A. Its potential to produce a large amount of energy, B. Its potential to produce a loud noise, C. Its safety and potential harm to humans and the environment, D. Its potential to produce a strong odor Correct Option: C
Question 12: What precaution should be taken when handling phosphorus? Options: A. Wear protective gloves to prevent skin contact, B. Store it in a well-ventilated area to prevent inhalation, C. Handle it with bare hands to increase reactivity, D. All of the above, including storing it under water to prevent reaction with oxygen Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
So here I’ve got a really nice sample of
silicon, alright? Ok. I’m going to take it out of the bottle…
of the… I’m going to have to wash my hands after this. So silicon is a very common element, it’s
particularly found in sand which is the oxide of silica; that’s
the compound of oxygen and silicon. It is also found in a variety of minerals
which contain silicon, oxygen and another metal which are known as
silicates. And silicates occur in an enormous number of different
minerals. It’s sort of the part of science that unless
you are a specialist you find quite boring but if you really go
into it like everything else it becomes really quite interesting. So this is a piece of polycrystalline silicon.
It’s a really quite fantastic element and it’s very often used,
or in fact it’s used very regularly to make electronic components.
All of the computers that we use and actually the camera
that you are recording me on now are based upon silicon
technology. Silicon is also extremely important and the
basis of most of the electronic devices we use: my watch, your
video camera, and also in computers. And if we look over
here, I have got here this is an example of a silicon wafer;
you can see at the back this is silicon. So the silicon is grown as a single crystal
from which we can make very highly-refined architectures on
silicon chips, but you see here we have a polycrystalline sample
so it is very pretty the way that it interacts with the
light and you can see the different grain sizes. So let me take it out. Did Martyn show you the single crystal, the
wafer? Yeah, he’s got a single chip, yeah, yeah. Cause if you can get the light coming off
it, you can get all sorts of different coloured affects. Here you can see, this is pure silicon on
the back and on the front, people have grown chips these are the
Pentium 4 chips for the computer, I think, I am not absolutely
sure but I think these are the chips and these are the connectors
on either side. So there are a whole lot of these chips
and they grow a large number of them at once. These are chopped
up and tested and the ones that worked are put into
computers and the ones that are no good are just chucked
and so this is a fantastically delicate piece of engineering
making these. This is so-called 20cm wafer. They now make silicon
chips on a 30cm wafer which is about this size and you
can get a large number more on them. If you get a single crystal of this silicon
structure, it can diffract the light and change the light so
that it diffracts and bends off at different angles so that you
get like a rainbow effect off it. It’s really quite beautiful. A compound of silicon, silicon nitride is
extremely tough and very light so it’s very difficult to break
and silicon nitride for example is used in the impellers in turbo
chargers in cars. So when you put your foot down on the accelerator
it will spin up very fast because it is very light but
it is very strong so it won’t very suddenly fall to bits as it is
revving up inside your engine. Right I must put that there because I want
to put that back in a bag.

wafer? Yeah, he’s got a single chip, yeah, yeah. Cause if you can get the light coming off
it, you can get all sorts of different coloured affects. Here you can see, this is pure silicon on
the back and on the front, people have grown chips these are the
Pentium 4 chips for the computer, I think, I am not absolutely
sure but I think these are the chips and these are the connectors
on either side. So there are a whole lot of these chips
and they grow a large number of them at once. These are chopped
up and tested and the ones that worked are put into
computers and the ones that are no good are just chucked
and so this is a fantastically delicate piece of engineering
making these. This is so-called 20cm wafer. They now make silicon
chips on a 30cm wafer which is about this size and you
can get a large number more on them. If you get a single crystal of this silicon
structure, it can diffract the light and change the light so
that it diffracts and bends off at different angles so that you
get like a rainbow effect off it. It’s really quite beautiful. A compound of silicon, silicon nitride is
extremely tough and very light so it’s very difficult to break
and silicon nitride for example is used in the impellers in turbo
chargers in cars. So when you put your foot down on the accelerator
it will spin up very fast because it is very light but
it is very strong so it won’t very suddenly fall to bits as it is
revving up inside your engine. Right I must put that there because I want
to put that back in a bag.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the name of inert silicon polymers that can be found in implants?
Options: A. Polystyrene, B. Silanes, C. Silicones
Correct Option: C

Question 4: Why is a single crystal of silicon grown in the process of creating silicon chips? Options: A. To increase the chip's durability, B. To enhance the chip's conductivity, C. To create a uniform base for fabrication, D. To reduce the chip's size Correct Option: C
Question 5: Which industry is a potential application of silicon nitride's unique properties, such as its toughness and lightness? Options: A. Aerospace, B. Automotive, C. Construction, D. Textile Correct Option: B

Question 7: What is the relationship between silicon and its compounds, such as silica and silicates? Options: A. They are mutually exclusive, B. They are interchangeable, C. Silicon is a component of silica and silicates, D. Silica and silicates are components of silicon Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the primary difference between polycrystalline and single-crystal silicon? Options: A. Their thermal conductivity, B. Their electronic conductivity, C. Their crystal structure, D. Their density Correct Option: C
Question 9: What could be a potential new application of silicon's properties in the field of renewable energy? Options: A. Developing more efficient solar panels, B. Creating more durable wind turbines, C. Enhancing the energy storage capacity of batteries, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What could be a potential outcome of integrating the understanding of silicon nitride's properties with its use in turbochargers? Options: A. Developing new materials for high-stress applications, B. Improving the efficiency of turbochargers, C. Reducing the cost of turbocharger production, D. Both A and B Correct Option: D

It is a crucial component with significant impact, C. It is a redundant component with no impact, D. It is an obsolete component with diminishing impact Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
So we're gonna go find some liquid Nitrogen. We keep it in a really large dewar tank at the back of the shop, so we're gonna go find that now.  So this is a dewar that we used to keep the liquid Nitrogen in within the building so it's much more convenient for us and our students to get it. So what we're gonna do now is we're gonna fill up our small dewar to carry the Nitrogen back to the lab. So you can probably hear it hissing and fizzing going into the bottle, and you can see all the Nitrogen evaporating off. Nitrogen exists as a gas. Molecules of N2. And it is interesting, because the bond between the two Nitrogen atoms is the strongest bond that you can get between any two atoms in the Periodic Table. Any two atoms that are the same. Sometimes, if you have two atoms that are different, the bond can be slightly stronger, but the NN triple bond is one of the strongest that you can have. So what we're doing is we're filling up the dewar with liquid Nitrogen so that we can take that back to our lab to do our next experiment. So many explosive compounds, things that you've heard of, like TNT and other explosives, all contain Nitrogen, which are isolated atoms, and when the explosion goes off the atoms come together and release energy. Nitrogen is used widely in laboratories, partly because it's not as reactive as Oxygen, so if you do an experiment in an atmosphere of Nitrogen you can avoid reactions that might occur with air. You can also use Nitrogen when it's liquified as a coolant. Liquid Nitrogen boils at -196 degrees Centigrade, 77 degrees absolute, and you can just hold it in a normal thermous flask. So this is a dewar of liquid Nitrogen, and you can see that the Nitrogen is evaporating from the top, coming out and frosting, coming down over the sides because it's a little bit more dense than the air. You can see it's heavily laden with ice, and you can see that the ice crystals are starting to grow on the top of the dewar here. It's very cold though, so we mustn't touch it for too long. So if we just tip some out on the floor, we can see that the Nitrogen itself will come out like a liquid, like pouring water,  but the interesting thing is, water, when I pour it on the floor it forms a puddle. It does nothing useful. In fact, it sort of gets in the way. But liquid Nitrogen, when I pour it on the floor, it forms these really quite nice bubbles, and they fly across  to the side of the room and take all the dust with them. Pretty cool. But if you put materials like rubber or flowers into liquid Nitrogen, instead of being soft and bendy they become really rigid, and you can smash them with a hammer. So you can see all of the bubbles forming on this steel tray now, and they're sweeping away all the dust quite nicely as they evaporate and move further afield. So Neil's got a piece of tubing, and it's really quite flexible tubing, you can see it's really floppy, and now he's gonna put it into the cryogenic liquid Nitrogen and freeze it, and see what happens to the rubber. But you see another interesting thing there is that the liquid Nitrogen is siphoning out through the tube, and that's a really good joke, because you can direct that siphon at someones trousers and freeze their legs. So I think that's enough, Neil, let's see if it's a bit harder. Wow, that shattered.  And there's quite a nice little operation that I've heard about, in which you can take the lens out of somebody's eye when they're suitably anaesthetized, and this lens can be frozen and then put on the lathe and you can change its shape so you get the right shape, and then you let it unfreeze, it goes soft again, and you pop it back into their eye. . . . . . . . . . . . .
Captions by www.SubPLY.com

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: On a packet of crisps (chips in the USA), you will often see something similar to “atmosphere of nitrogen” written on the packet. Why is the pack full of nitrogen instead of air?
Options: A. Because nitrogen is an inert gas (like the noble gases) and, unlike air which contains oxygen, cannot damage the food, B. Because the nitrogen gives a really good taste to the crisps - a nitrogen flavor!, C. Because nitrogen is cheaper than air
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of container is typically used to store Liquid Nitrogen due to its extremely low temperature? Options: A. A thermally insulated flask, B. A dewar tank, C. A metal flask with a loose lid, D. A plastic bottle with a tight seal Correct Option: B
Question 2: At what temperature does Liquid Nitrogen boil in degrees Centigrade? Options: A. -100, B. -196, C. 0, D. 100 Correct Option: B
Question 3: Why is Nitrogen often preferred over Oxygen in laboratory settings? Options: A. Nitrogen is more reactive than Oxygen, B. Nitrogen is less expensive than Oxygen, C. Nitrogen is less reactive than Oxygen, reducing unwanted reactions, D. Nitrogen has a higher boiling point than Oxygen Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is a significant consequence of the strong bond between Nitrogen atoms? Options: A. High reactivity, B. Utility in explosive compounds due to energy release when bonds form, C. Poor cooling properties, D. Good heat conduction Correct Option: B
Question 5: A laboratory experiment requires a coolant that can rapidly freeze materials. Which of the following would be a suitable choice? Options: A. Liquid Oxygen, B. Liquid Nitrogen, C. Liquid Helium, D. Liquid Hydrogen Correct Option: B
Question 6: A researcher wants to reshape an eye lens in a medical procedure. Which of the following could be used to achieve this? Options: A. Liquid Nitrogen, B. Liquid Oxygen, C. Laser technology, D. Ultrasonic waves Correct Option: A
Question 7: How does the strong bond between Nitrogen atoms contribute to its role in explosive compounds? Options: A. Decreases utility, B. Increases utility due to energy release when bonds form, C. No impact, D. Slightly increases utility Correct Option: B
Question 8: How does the reactivity of Nitrogen compare to that of Oxygen in laboratory settings? Options: A. Nitrogen is more reactive than Oxygen, B. Nitrogen is less reactive than Oxygen, C. Nitrogen and Oxygen have similar reactivity, D. Nitrogen's reactivity is not comparable to Oxygen's Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is a potential hazard associated with handling Liquid Nitrogen in a laboratory? Options: A. Explosions due to high reactivity, B. Burns or frostbite due to extremely low temperature, C. Contamination due to high purity, D. Equipment damage due to low viscosity Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a potential benefit of using Nitrogen in medical procedures? Options: A. It can cause unwanted reactions with air, B. It can lead to the creation of explosive compounds, C. It can provide a safe and effective means of freezing and reshaping tissues, D. It can increase the risk of contamination Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: "Why is Nitrogen often preferred over Oxygen in laboratory settings?" 

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks why a packet of crisps is filled with nitrogen instead of air. Both questions are related to the use of nitrogen as a substitute for air or oxygen due to its inert properties. 

The correct option in Question 3, "Nitrogen is less reactive than Oxygen, reducing unwanted reactions," is also similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "Because nitrogen is an inert gas (like the noble gases) and, unlike air which contains oxygen, cannot damage the food."

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the School of Chemistry at the University of Nottingham, there is a lift (elevator) with a sign that states, “Danger! Risk of Asphyxiation. Do not ride in the lift with dewars containing cryogenic liquids”. Why?
Options: A. Because nitrogen gas is toxic, B. Because nitrogen gas can displace the air (and with it, the oxygen that we need), C. Because breathing liquid nitrogen can freeze your respiratory system
Correct Option: B

Question: What is the fog that can be seen around the dewar flask of liquid nitrogen?
Options: A. Nitrogen gas evaporating from the liquid, B. A product of the reaction between nitrogen gas and oxygen from the air, C. Water condensate from the water vapour in the air
Correct Option: C

So many explosive compounds, things that you've heard of, like TNT and other explosives, all contain Nitrogen, which are isolated atoms, and when the explosion goes off the atoms come together and release energy. Nitrogen is used widely in laboratories, partly because it's not as reactive as Oxygen, so if you do an experiment in an atmosphere of Nitrogen you can avoid reactions that might occur with air. You can also use Nitrogen when it's liquified as a coolant. Liquid Nitrogen boils at -196 degrees Centigrade, 77 degrees absolute, and you can just hold it in a normal thermous flask. So this is a dewar of liquid Nitrogen, and you can see that the Nitrogen is evaporating from the top, coming out and frosting, coming down over the sides because it's a little bit more dense than the air. You can see it's heavily laden with ice, and you can see that the ice crystals are starting to grow on the top of the dewar here. It's very cold though, so we mustn't touch it for too long. So if we just tip some out on the floor, we can see that the Nitrogen itself will come out like a liquid, like pouring water,  but the interesting thing is, water, when I pour it on the floor it forms a puddle. It does nothing useful. In fact, it sort of gets in the way. But liquid Nitrogen, when I pour it on the floor, it forms these really quite nice bubbles, and they fly across  to the side of the room and take all the dust with them. Pretty cool. But if you put materials like rubber or flowers into liquid Nitrogen, instead of being soft and bendy they become really rigid, and you can smash them with a hammer. So you can see all of the bubbles forming on this steel tray now, and they're sweeping away all the dust quite nicely as they evaporate and move further afield. So Neil's got a piece of tubing, and it's really quite flexible tubing, you can see it's really floppy, and now he's gonna put it into the cryogenic liquid Nitrogen and freeze it, and see what happens to the rubber. But you see another interesting thing there is that the liquid Nitrogen is siphoning out through the tube, and that's a really good joke, because you can direct that siphon at someones trousers and freeze their legs. So I think that's enough, Neil, let's see if it's a bit harder. Wow, that shattered.  And there's quite a nice little operation that I've heard about, in which you can take the lens out of somebody's eye when they're suitably anaesthetized, and this lens can be frozen and then put on the lathe and you can change its shape so you get the right shape, and then you let it unfreeze, it goes soft again, and you pop it back into their eye. . . . . . . . . . . . .
Captions by www.SubPLY.com

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the order of the bond between the two nitrogen atoms of molecular nitrogen?
Options: A. Single, B. Double, C. Triple
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
So the blue one in the middle of this series
is argon, so again this is a very nice glass tube that we’ve had made
with a low pressure of argon inside. We’ve put a potential across from
the two ends, here and here, and this excites all the argon molecules inside
so you can see this wonderful characteristic eerie blue glow coming
off from the argon. Argon is one of the noble gases or so-called
rare gases. It’s not really quite so rare. It consists in really quite
a high percentage, nearly one percent of the atmosphere. If I look at the one in the middle I can see
lots and lots of lines in the blue and the green region and these are all
specific to the individual atoms that are in the tubes themselves. But it’s very un-reactive so early chemists
found it quite difficult to identify, in fact it was only Sir William
Ramsey that identified the argon in 1894 and he was in fact the first person in
Britain to win a Nobel Prize for chemistry. So if we turn off the power to this, we turn
off the potential and then we don’t excite the molecules so what we’d
see is just a clear glass tube with no visible sign of anything inside. And
only when we turn on the potential that we excite the molecules, so
they emit and give us these really quite wonderful colours.

**Transcript**:
So Potassium metal is very reactive.  One of my colleagues who used to work with it, described it as evil.  So we've come out behind the chemistry department. In the open air. To try and do  a re-take of the Potassium video.  The last sample of Potassium was very very small, maybe 500mg.  It will react, it is so reactive that if you have it  in a box with Argon, so that it can't get Oxygen from anywhere, it will take the Oxygen out of paper. Which is, paper is a compound of Carbon, Hydrogen and Oxygen. And it can extract this.  It's a reactive element. It's used in our body all the time. We have like, lots of Potassium floating around. And we've got some samples here, about a gram, maybe a gram and a half of each. It's a pretty big chunk of Potassium this.  Ready? Yeah. Very satisfying reaction.  After completing the 100 meters dash... Like Sodium it'ss quite a low melting point metal. And if you mix Sodium and Potassium together, to make so called Sodium Potassium amalgam, it's called NaK, by those who work in the trade, Na for Sodium, K for Potassium. NaK is a liquid at room temperature. It looks a bit like Mercury. A silver liquid. It's very light. And I never played with it, but people say that if you try and drop it on the floor, it will burst into flames before it hits the floor, because it reacts with the water in the air. Today I'm going to show you how to make a Potassium mirror. We will just fish out a nice little bit of Potassium. It's stored under mineral oil, because it reacts with water over time.  So it's quite malleable stuff. It's a little bit like if you imagine cutting Blu Tac. It's quite soft.  And it starts you see, it's starting to go a little bit already. Tarnishing a wee bit. So we can just manipulate it like that, and we are gonna pop it into our ampule, and we are gonna evacuate it now. I'm gonna remove all  of the atmosphere, from this ampule.  OK, we've done that because the, the boiling point of Potassium under one atmosphere is over 700 degrees C. Which is pretty high. It's too high for the glass to tolerate. If I heated it up to that temperature the glass would start to soften, melt. So by evacuating it, we remove all of the atmosphere which is keeping the boiling point as high as it is. So it lowers the boiling point  much lower. So it starts to drop into the range of water.   OK so we are just going to the blue flame, which is the nice hot flame.  And we just keep on gently warming it. And at some point, it will melt. Just enough that you will start to see bubbles  of Potassium just jumping out of this thin oxide layer, which is coating it at the minute. Now it's starting to form. So the reason we do it like this is that we end up with a  large surface of Potassium, so it's excellent for  keeping our solvents dry.  So what we've got now, is we've got the ampule, and all the way up here, this is literally a mirror of very thin Potassium.  Potassium is very important. Our bodies contain quite  a lot of Potassium. And it's in all sorts of biological material. If you burn  garden rubbish, in the ash that you get in the end is Potassium, which is presumably why it's called Potash. So as Neil quite literally wets the wall, to get rid of all the un-reacted Potassium. Wicked.  One of my colleagues  who used to work with it, described it as evil.  Captions by www.SubPLY.com

Question 3: Why is Potassium considered challenging to work with? Options: A. Due to its low melting point, B. Due to its high reactivity, C. Due to its high density, D. Due to its low availability Correct Option: B
